sn11.24:1.2: Now at that time two mendicants were overly attached,
sn11.24:1.3: and one of them transgressed against the other.
sn11.24:1.4: The transgressor confessed to the other mendicant,
sn11.24:1.6: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
sn11.24:2.2: One who doesn’t recognize when they’ve made a mistake. And one who doesn’t properly accept the confession of someone who’s made a mistake.
sn11.24:2.4: There are two who are astute.
sn11.24:2.5: One who recognizes when they’ve made a mistake. And one who properly accepts the confession of someone who’s made a mistake.
sn11.24:2.6: These are the two who are astute.
sn11.24:3.1: Once upon a time, mendicants, Sakka, lord of gods, guiding the gods of the Thirty-Three, recited this verse:
